In Julia, Write a function `timezone_bumper(dt,bump)` that increases any provided timestamp by `bump::Int` hours (defaults to +3 hours). Make sure it works only for DateTime types and throws an error for Date types.

Here is the Julia code to solve this problem:

```julia
using Dates

function timezone_bumper(dt::DateTime, bump=3)
    return dt + Hour(bump)
end

function timezone_bumper(dt::Date)
    error("This function does not support Date types. Please use DateTime instead.")
end
```
In this code, `timezone_bumper` is a function that takes in two arguments: `dt`, which is the date-time to be modified and `bump`, which is an integer representing how many hours you want to add to the time. If no `bump` value is provided, it defaults to 3 hours.

The first function checks if the input type is DateTime. If it is, it adds the number of hours specified by `bump` to the date-time and returns the result.

The second function checks if the input type is Date. If it is, it throws an error saying that this function does not support Date types.
